resources.string: Welcome to Project Ina! This app was created in order to help pregnant women in your reservation learn more about what happens before, during, and after pregnancy, making the process just a little bit easier.
See the tutorial below for step by step instructions on how to use this app.
Recommendations for people to contact based on your message history
What Is This App All About?

Women have the unique ability to create and maintain life. Because of this incredible experience, women’s health is extremely important, not only to individual women, but also to future generations. Project Ina is a platform to connect you with your local resources, helpful community members, and other mothers, all while giving you important information on your pregnancy and motherhood experience. While this app is here for you to learn more about your health and get connected to resources in your area, ultimately you are in charge of your own health and you know what’s best for your future baby. 

Focusing on your health begins before the baby is even conceived. (Conception happens when a woman’s egg meets a man’s sperm cell. This is the first step in combining the traits of the woman and man to form a baby). During this time, you should follow an appropriate diet, make sure you have all the proper vaccines, are taking the medications that you need to, and are doing the right amount of physical activity. This sounds like a lot of work to do even before you become pregnant! But making sure that both your mind and body are ready for pregnancy is extremely important for yourself and your future baby. You should have a say in (1) when you want to have kids, (2) how many kids you want, and (3) the spacing between your kids. Family planning methods can help you be in control of these three questions. 

If you decide that it’s the right time for you to have a child, it’s important that you’re in a nurturing environment that has opportunities for social and intellectual growth. Unhealthy environments may include exposure to secondhand smoke (Secondhand smoke occurs if you are near people that smoke and accidentally breathe in their smoke.), environmental toxins (poisonous or cancer-causing substances in the environment), unsafe drugs, and even emotional stress. There are many resources in the SWO community and within this app that can help you to eliminate these harmful elements and promote a healthy environment. 

This app can help you to navigate the medical experience of pregnancy. Doctor appointments can be stressful, especially if you don’t always understand why certain procedures are being done. Through this app, you can learn more about how your baby is developing throughout your pregnancy, pre-natal procedures, complications of pregnancy, and delivery procedures. If you’re the type of person that finds comfort in planning, you can use the “Checklist” feature in this app to make sure you are going to all your appointments, finding a way to pay for pregnancy care, and preparing for delivery. You can even make your own check-lists. The “Events” page will help you to connect with other mothers and community members at SWO events. 

The Project Ina team hopes that this app helps you to have a healthy pregnancy and motherhood experience!

Fertilization after conception (Weeks 0 – 2) 
• For women, an ovum (an “egg”) is released from the ovary usually every month 
• During sex, when sperm from the male enters the fallopian tube through the vagina and cervix, it fertilizes the ovum 
• The fertilized egg, with genes from both parents, begins to rapidly grow and divide in the first two weeks 

Implantation (Week 3) 
• Protective liquid, called the amniotic fluid, begins to collect in womb of the mother, also called the amniotic sac. 
• The fertilized egg is now a small clump of several hundred rapidly dividing cells 
• Cells of the embryo (the baby) arrange themselves into two layers 
• Cells of the placenta produce a hormone for the baby called human chorionic gonadotrophin 
• The placenta is an organ in the mother that nourishes and maintains the fetus through the umbilical cord 

Early development (Weeks 4-7) 
• Neural tube develops, beginning with the spine 
• Yolk sac, which generates the baby’s blood cells, develops 
• Arm, leg, tailbone, eyelid, and jaw structures begin to develop 
• The umbilical cord begins to loop into the baby’s intestines 
• The mother will experience increased need for urination due to increased internal fluid volumes 

Month 2-3 (Week 8 – 13) 
• Earlobes, neural networks in the brain, knees, fingers, wrists, and shoulders begin to develop 
• Uterus has doubled in size 
• Chorionic villi sampling, which is a test that detects early abnormalities in the fetus, occurs at this stage. A tiny tissue sample is taken from the fetus part of the placenta. 
• Bones begin to solidify, and skin remains translucent 

Month 4 (Week 14 – 17) 
• The baby’s urinary and circulatory systems are operational 
• Limbs continue to grow, and all joints completely develop 
• Toenails, and a thin sheath of hair known as lanugo, have developed 

Month 5 (Week 18 – 22) 
• Ultrasounds and birth defect screening should occur at this point, check with your doctor 
• Vernix caseosa, a greasy outer cover, develops over the baby’s skin to protect it from damage within the amniotic fluid 
• The sensory system develops in the brain 
• Eyes develop, but the irises still lack pigmentation 
• Tooth buds and lips begin to become distinct 
• The mother will begin showing, as the uterus enlarges further 

Month 6 (Week 23 – 27) 
• Uterus pressure can cause edema in the mother, or swelling caused by excess fluid 
• Taste buds and hair texture and color are now recognizable 
• Eyes can now be opened and closed, male genitals and the respiratory system begin to develop 

Month 7 (Week 28 – 32) 
• The baby has developed eyelashes, taste buds, fingernails, and toenails 
• The baby grows to about 3.75 pounds and 16.7 inches long 
• The skeleton is solidified, and fat cells accumulate under the skin 
• STD testing is critical here for the mother 
• Preeclampsia is more prevalent here, and should be tested for 

Month 8 (Week 33 – 37) 
• Babies now have temperature regulation, due to fat accumulation, and ~99 percent can survive outside of the womb at this point 
• Skull bones begin to constrict to make passage through the birth canal easier 
• Protective coverings on the skin and hari, the vernix caseosa and lanugo, are shed 
• Facial muscles are developed enough so that babies can smile 
• The baby will grow about an ounce a day, and should be around 19 inches long 
• Labor, both false and actual, is possible by now and the uterus continues to enlarge 

Month 9 (Week 38 – 41) 
• Lung maturation is completed, as is initial eye coloration 
• Soft spots in the skull form, and may last up to a year after delivery 
• Hair and nails continue to grow, even past the fingers, scalp, and toes 
• The amniotic fluid can “break,” signifying the start of labor 
• The average baby, by now, is amount 7.5 pounds and 20 inches long

How can I tell if I’m pregnant? 
Early signs of pregnancy may include: 
• Missed period 
• Nausea 
• Unusual tiredness 
• Full, tender breasts 
• Frequent urination 
• Change in appetite 
• Vaginal spotting 

If you think you’re pregnant, you can either buy a pregnancy test from the store (available at Shopko for around $40) or contact your medical provider at IHS or elsewhere to arrange for a pregnancy test. It’s quick and painless, and normally it only requires a urine sample, and IHS should do it for free. The urine test is considered accurate if you are at least 2 weeks “late” for her expected period (or 6 weeks after the start of your last period if your cycle is irregular). You can also get a blood test to check if you’re pregnant. The doctor might also give you an internal exam or perform an ultrasound exam to confirm. 

If you’re pregnant, there are many sources of advice and assistance in the SWO community to help you throughout your pregnancy. 
• Talk with as many people as you are comfortable speaking with to learn about their pregnancy experiences. Speaking with your parents, grandparents, siblings, cousins, and friends can help with understanding what’s normal and what isn’t. Talking with elders about the significance of your pregnancy in the Dakota culture can help you to find a sense of purpose throughout your experience. 

• Arrange for proper prenatal care by calling IHS’s prenatal care clinic if you live close to downtown Sisseton. Prenatal care means you or a doctor prepare for your baby to be born and make sure both you and your baby are healthy.

If you have a relationship with the baby’s father during pregnancy, the relationship may vary in terms of labels. However, having a healthy relationship with him can help to lower your own stress during pregnancy and make for a better environment for a baby to come into. What is a healthy relationship? 

• A safe space where you and your partner are able to express feelings. 

• Sharing the the joys and pains of life helps you both to grow as a couple and as individuals. 

• No abuse 

• You both support each other in good times and when times are tough. 

• You both are determined to work on the relationship and help it succeed. 

• You’re committed to each other in every way, sexually and emotionally. 

• Both of your material needs (food, water, clothes, shelter) are being met. 

• Encourages positive values 

• You both have a common vision, share basic values, have the other person’s interests at heart, and are strong individuals. 

• Each person appreciates the other’s unique contributions to the relationship. 

• You are together because you want to be - not because you fear being alone, want sex, or seek revenge on an ex-partner. 

• Your relationship is equal, meaning that you make decisions together, respect each other’s boundaries, and are a team. 

• You both avoid competition. Instead you respect each other’s way of doing things, cooperate with each other, work as equal partners, and help each other reach goals. 

• You both are assertive, rather than aggressive, in your communications with each other. The difference between aggression and assertion in relationships is that aggressive people try to control others. They think in terms of ‘winning and losing’. They tend to make unreasonable demands, threats, or excuses for themselves. Being assertive helps relationships by stating your needs and wants without attacking, blaming, or making excuses. It means you stand up for your rights and can say no when you need to. You are direct about your feelings without apologizing for them and respect the rights of others.

In high school or college, you may start to explore your sexuality. How you define your own personal boundaries is completely up to you! It’s always important to make sure, though, that you practice safe sex and communicate that with your sexual partner(s). It’s just as much their responsibility as it is yours. If neither you nor our partner are using birth control, there’s a possibility that you’ll become pregnant. While pregnancy can be an amazing experience, if you aren’t on the same page as your partner or if you have other plans for yourself besides being a mother, this experience can be stressful. Waiting to have children can help you to finish high school without interruption, pursue a college degree, and even finding a meaningful job. In other words, you can discover and understand yourself before being responsible for someone else. See the “Family Planning” section to learn how to prevent pregnancy and STI’s while still being sexually active. 

Having a baby can have far-reaching effects for you. It may mean deciding about marriage, changing education and career plans, finding a place to live, and learning how to handle finances. It comes with increased responsibilities, like taking care of all of a baby’s physical needs: feeding, changing, bathing, dressing, etc. It means providing the love and attention a baby needs to thrive and caring for a baby that’s crying, fussy, or sick. 

If you’re a teenager and just found out that you’re pregnant, you may be feeling overwhelmed or helpless. Don’t worry, there are so many resources and people on the reservation that can help you through this experience! 
• Your parents 
• Your brothers and sisters 
• Your other family (aunts, uncles, cousins) 
• Your friends 
• Maternal Health resources such as Indian Health Service, Coteau Healthcare System, WIC, and Early Head Start. This app contains more resources and how to navigate them.

Drinking alcohol during pregnancy can cause a birth defect called Fetal Alcohol Syndrome or FAS. The placenta grows in your uterus (womb) and supplies your baby with food and oxygen through the umbilical cord during pregnancy. If you drink alcohol, it freely passes directly through the placenta and umbilical cord to your baby. The alcohol can affect growing cells, especially those in the baby’s brain. The more you drink, the higher your baby’s risk of developing problems that will last a lifetime. Alcohol can also pass through breast milk to your baby and can harm your baby. 

Drinking alcohol during pregnancy can cause: 
	• Premature birth (before 37 weeks) 
	• Low birthweight (less than 5 pounds, 8 oz.) 
	• Heart defects 
	• Unusual facial features 
	• Reduced IQ 
	• Vision and hearing problems 
	• Learning and behavior problems 
	• Miscarriage (death of baby before 20 weeks of pregnancy) 

You may find it difficult to change your drinking habits during pregnancy. Alcohol is often part of social activities, like parties and sports events. Here are some tips that may help: 
	• Think about when you usually drink alcohol. Plan things to have instead, like fruity drinks or water. 
	• Tell your friends and family you don’t want to drink alcohol during pregnancy. Ask them to help and support you. 
	• Get rid of all the alcohol in your home. 
	• Stay away from places where you usually drink alcohol like at parties or bars. 
	• We do not know a safe level of alcohol during pregnancy so it is best to avoid drinking any alcohol. 

If you need help to stop drinking alcohol 
	• Tell your healthcare provider 
	• Call the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence or visit their website (1-800-622-2255 or ncadd.org) 
	• Call the Alcohol Detox Center in Serenity Hills, Watertown at 605-884-0650

It’s important for you to be in a good mental and physical state before you begin to take care of another life within you. The Center for Disease Control suggests that every woman do the following every year, especially if they’re trying to become pregnant: 
• Eat healthy foods (see Healthy Diet page) 
• Stay active (Try to get 150 minutes of moderate exercise each week) 
• Take 400 micrograms (mcg) of folic acid daily, which will help prevent birth defects. You can either eat fortified foods or take a supplement daily, which can be found at Walmart or the local convenience store. 
• Maintain a healthy weight, which is about 18.5-24.9. Being both underweight and overweight can mean you are less likely to become pregnant and can also make your pregnancy more risky. 
• Protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Practice safe sex, and see your OB/Gyn if you think you may have been exposed to a STI. If you do have an STI. 
• If you find out that you have an STI, take medicine for the full time as directed. 
• Avoid harmful chemicals, metals, and toxic substances around the home and workplace. 
• Make sure your vaccinations are up to date 
• Manage your mental health and stress (see IHS Department of Psychology) 
• If you smoke or use substances, this could be a good time to quit 
	• Use 1-800-QUIT-NOW (1-800-784-8669) 
	• Avoid street drugs and other people’s prescription medications 
	• Limit alcohol consumption 
• If you’re in a situation of partner violence, talk to a doctor or counselor about ways that you can manage the situation. IHS has a Department of Behavioral Health with trained counselors you can talk to. 
• Be aware of any health conditions, such as asthma, diabetes, or obesity 
• Learn about your family’s health and ask a doctor about any risks or diseases that you may be worried about passing onto your baby. 
• Get regular check-ups with your doctor. Below are all of the doctors present at Coteau Hospital, where you must make arrangements to deliver your baby 
	• Dr. Judy Beumer 
	• Dr. David Oey 
	• Dr. Linda Peterson, OB/GYN 
	• Dr. Stanley Gallagher 
	• Bradley Gallagher, PA-C 
	• Jackie Bartlett, PA-C 
	• Angie Gaikowski, NCP 
	• Dr. David Meadows 
	• Dr. Shira Tomboulian 

	• Nate Tiedeman, DNCP 
	• Call 605-698-7681 to schedule an appointment at the Coteau Hospital.

When you’re pregnant, everything that you eat affects both you and your baby, so it can sometimes be stressful to find foods that are nutritious for the both of you. When you’re pregnant, you also need more of certain vitamins and minerals. You can take vitamin supplements while also maintaining a healthy diet. You can talk to the SWO Health Education Department, the Coteau Young at Heart Weight Management Program, and IHS General Care for more information on a healthy diet. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has excellent advice (www.choosemyplate.gov) to help pregnant women and new mothers. On this website, you can add information about you, like your age, height, and weight, and find a diet plan for you for your three trimesters and through breastfeeding (https://www.choosemyplate.gov/MyPlate-Daily-Checklist-input). This website is based on the 5 food groups grains, fruits, vegetables, protein, and dairy. Oils and fats are also important, because they provide important nutrients, but solid fats from animals should be limited. If you’re expecting more than one baby, talk to your doctor about what is healthy for you. 

A general healthy diet for pregnant moms are below, but you can get personalized diet from either your doctor or from the daily checklist on the USDA website (https://www.choosemyplate.gov/MyPlate-Daily-Checklist-input). 

Grains 
	6-8 ounces 
	Aim for whole grains for at least half of daily grain choices 

Vegetables 
	2.5-3.5 cups 

Fruits 
	2 cups 

Milk/Milk Products 
	4 cups 

Proteins 
	5-6.5 ounces 

Oils 
	6-7 teaspoons 

Water 
	8-10 cups 

Vitamins 
	Prenatal vitamin every day 
	Vitamin D (from milk or being in the sun): helps to build your baby’s teeth and bones 
	Calcium (from milk-products): helps to build your baby’s teeth and bones 
	Iron: helps to make red blood cells, which carry oxygen to your baby 

Fish/Shellfish 
Omega-3 fatty acids are found naturally in many kinds of fish. 2 servings should eaten each week during pregnancy to help develop the baby’s brain. You should avoid fish that might contain mercury, such as shark, swordfish, king mackerel or tilefish. You should also limit white tuna to 6 ounces per week.

During pregnancy, it’s important for your physical and mental health that you keep yourself safe from abuse. If you are being abused in your relationship, remember that abuse is never your fault. 

So what is partner abuse? 
There are many types of abuse, but the most common are physical, emotional or sexual mistreatment by a partner. 
• Physical: can involve pushing, slapping, punching, kicking, using a weapon, or using force that causes pain or injury. 
• Emotional: uses threats of harm to you or your family members, friends, or possessions; deprives you of money, sleep, or affection; harasses you at work or at home; insults or verbally abuses you; uses any type of behavior to cause you emotional pain 
• Sexual mistreatment: forcing you to perform sexual acts that you have not consented to 

Sometimes you can be unsure of when something is abuse. Some warning signs and common characteristics of abusers include: 
• Having a poor self-image and may be unable to control their own lives 
• Acting “bossy” and controlling 
• Controlling your access to money 
• Have witnessed abuse as children or were abused themselves 
• Viewing violence as a natural part of family life 
• Abusing alcohol or other drugs, and even using it as an excuse for abuse 
• Not communicating well and having trouble expressing feelings 
• Feeling intense jealousy 
• Having a violent temper 
• Ignoring or mocking your needs and ideas 

If don’t think your situation is abusive, but are worried that it might lead to abuse in the future, you can play a part in preventing partner abuse at home by: 
• Setting an example for your children by following a “no violence” rule 
• Resolving problems by talking things over in an understanding, empathetic way 
• Getting help if you and your partner can’t resolve problems 

The cycle of abuse follows a 3-stage pattern for many couples: 
(1) Tension building: This is a time of minor conflicts and, possibly, some physical abuse. This stage may last from a few hours to many months. The victim is aware of the building tension and tries to please and humor the abuse. 
(2) A major episode of violence: This may be triggered by a small quarrel. Once an attack starts, there’s usually little the victim can do to stop it. Apologizing or reasoning with the abuser seldom works. 
(3) A period of remorse: The abuser feels ashamed and guilty, promising it will never happen again. The abuser may be on best behavior for a while and treat the victim with great kindness and generosity. But sooner or later, the cycle starts again. However, some abusers may never apologize or feel remorse. They may create an atmosphere of constant tension and abuse. 

If you’re in an abusive relationship, you may feel trapped. You may find it hard to leave due to fear of more violence or of isolation. You may also be financially dependent on your abuser and may find it difficult to come up with the funds to leave. You may have to choose between staying in the abusive relationship or leaving your children to your abuser. You may not believe it’s right to leave your husband under any circumstances. You may hope that your abuser will change his ways. 

Ask yourself the following questions to decide whether or not your abuser has changed and if your home is safe for you: 
• Is he still jealous? 
• Has he stopped being violent or threatening? 
• Has he stopped criticizing? 
• Am I still afraid when I’m with him? 
• Can he be angry without yelling or hitting? 
• Can I express anger toward him without being attacked? 
• Can he hear and respect what I say? 

No matter your obstacles, always remember that abuse is never your fault and that there are many people in the SWO community that can help you. 

What you can do if you are a victim of abuse: 
• Talk about the situation with someone can help (a friend, relative, therapist, crisis center counselor, priest or minister, or other trained professional). Asking for help is the first and biggest step to stopping the violence . 
• Try to have as much control over money as you can. Having your own money can make it easier to control some of the family income. Try to keep all property, including house and cars, in both your names. 
• Make a list of your skills and strengths as a person. These skills are yours, and your abuser can’t take them away from you. Find ways to use these skills and strengths in your everyday tasks to find a sense of control. If possible, find a job that allows you to use your unique skills. 

Make a safety plan if you are a victim of abuse so that you will be able to escape under extreme circumstances. 
• Think of a safe place you can go, and figure out how you will get there. 
• Keep important items handy. You may want to store some of these things with a person you can trust. 
	• Money 
	• Clothes 
	• An extra set of house and car keys 
	• Needed medications 
	• Important papers, such as driver’s license, birth certificates and medical records 
	• Important telephone numbers 
• Change your phone number, and ask everyone not to give out your new number or address 
• Vary your routine (travel different routes to work, use different stores, etc.) 
• If the abuser has left, change locks on all doors and make sure windows lock 

What to do during an attack: 
• Get away if you can, or defend yourself as best you can. 
• Call 911 if possible. Write down officer’s names and badge numbers in case a record of the attack is needed. 
• Leave the house and, if you have children, take them with you. 
• Seek medical help. Injuries may be more serious than they seem. Also, if you decide to press charges, having a record of the injuries can help. 
• Where to get help 
	• Disaster Distress Hotline: 1-800-985-5990. Administered by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Administration. Offers support coping methods, and counseling, during, before, and after disasters. 
	• Native Youth Crisis Line: 1-877-209-1266. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline has specific resources for Native American Youth, and their 24-hour hotline acknowledges the particular struggles of Native Youth battling with depression and suicide. 
	• Women’s Circle: 605-698-4129. Domestic Violence Shelter in Sisseton. 605 is their daytime number, 24/7 hotline is 888-200-4459 
	• Sisseton Police: 605-698-3932. Working to protect and serve the Sisseton community. Keeps a sex offender registry, makes arrests, intervenes in cases of harm. 
	• Roberts County Sheriff: 605-698-7667. South Dakota State official, designated with apprehending on behalf of the courts and enforcing warrants. 
	• SWO Tribal Police: 605-698-7661. Contracted and supported through tribal funds, defend both the tribal constitution and the constitution of the United States. 
	• Women of Nations Eagle Shelter: 1-877-209-1266. 24-hour crisis hotline for battered American Indian women and legal counsel support. 
	• Woodrow Wilson Keeble Healthcare Center: 605-698-7606. Local IHS building, emergency service and psychological counseling. 
	• Coteau Des Prairies Clinic: 605-698-7681. General health care, open 9-5pm Monday through Friday. 
	• Coteau Des Prairies Hospital: 605-698-7647. Widest variety of services available in the area including emergency room, OBG and gynecology, and fitness programs. 
	• SWO Child Protection Program: 605-698-3992. Tribal run program that seeks to protect vulnerable children while keeping families intact. 
	• Volunteers of America-Family Crisis Intervention: 605-380-8023. Prevention and early intervention program for South Dakota, diverts youth and family involvement in the Juvenile Justice System. 
	• Dakota Pride: 605-698-3917. Local resource for drug and substance abuse prevention, intervention, and recovery. 
	• National BIA Child Abuse Hotline: 1-800- 633-5166. Information, intervention, social services, counseling, and referrals 24/7.

Smoking: 
When you smoke, your baby is exposed to the same chemicals that you inhale in the cigarette smoke. Smoking during pregnancy can cause miscarriage, low birth weight babies, and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) (Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is the unexplained death, usually during sleep, of a seemingly healthy baby less than a year old).


Some moms start smoking again after the baby is born, but infants who are exposed to secondhand smoke (Secondhand smoke is smoke that has been breathed out by the person smoking) after birth are also at a greater risk of SIDS. Kids exposed to secondhand smoke get sick more often with illnesses like bronchitis, pneumonia, wheezing, coughing, and ear infections. Remember, there is no risk-free level of exposure to secondhand smoke. Smoking is also harmful to your own health. If you need help quitting, you can call 1-866-SD-QUITS .


Methamphetamine (Meth ): 
The Dakota Pride Center is the main resource on the reservation to seek help from serious drug addiction like meth. 

Meth, an extremely addictive drug, can damage brain cells, affect memory, cause hallucinations, and decrease your appetite If you use meth, you may feel angry and violent, especially when the drug wears off. You may do things that you normally wouldn’t do. Meth may make you stay awake for long periods of time, and feel anxious, afraid, paranoid, or depressed when it wears off. Other effects of using meth may include: 
	• high fevers 
	• stomach cramps 
	• weight loss 
	• raised blood pressure 
	• breathing problems 
	• convulsions (seizures) 
	• bleeding in the brain (stroke) 
	• heart failure and death


Smoking and inhaling meth can damage your lungs and nose. Sharing needles or syringes when injecting meth puts you at risk for HIV and hepatitis C. Using meth regularly may cause the teeth to turn black and start to crumble.


Using meth while you’re pregnant can cause your baby to be delivered before it’s fully developed (premature delivery) and the separation of your placenta from your uterus. Once your baby is born, your baby can become lethargic and even develop heart and brain abnormalities. Using meth during pregnancy impacts your child’s entire life. Children whose mothers used meth during pregnancy have trouble with attention, are more stressed and less aroused.


Meth is an illegal drug, and you could be arrested for possession of meth. If you are convicted, you could go to prison - even if you are pregnant. However, if you seek help at Dakota Pride, their number one goal is to ensure your health and the health of the baby. They keep your situation confidential and will never turn you into the police for seeking help.

string.name: mental_health_title
string.b: Mental Health Issues During and After Pregnancy

resources.string:
Many new mothers get the ‘baby blues’. While you may feel joyous, it’s normal to also feel tired from the hard work of childbirth and caring for a newborn, or isolated because you’re not with friends or doing your usual activities. The ‘baby blues’ can start a few days after birth. They usually go away in a couple of weeks. Post-partum depression (PPD) is a mental health condition that some women have after childbirth-sometimes starting up to a year later. It is more serious and lasts longer than the ‘baby blues’.


What causes PPD? 
• No one really knows for sure. Changes in hormone levels after birth play a role as well as a personal or family history of depression, the demands of taking care of a baby, and a more difficult birth. 
• Stress can play a role, especially when there is a lack of support from family or friends. Relationship or money problems, other big life changes, lack of sleep, changes in work or home schedules can cause stress. The belief that you can ‘do it all’ is also stressful. You may also be at higher risk if you’ve had severe Premenstrual Syndrome in the past.


Effects of PPD: 
• PPD can affect how you bond with your baby. You may have little desire to care for your baby and avoid holding or playing with your baby. You may feel angry with your baby and even think about hurting him or her. 
•PPD can affect how your baby grows. Your baby needs your love and care to grow and thrive. Without proper care and bonding, your baby may have delays in language development or problems with learning and good behavior. 
If you have any of the following thoughts often or lasting for 2 weeks or more, call your healthcare provider or talk to a trusted nurse or prenatal doctor. You can call the Sisseton IHS Mental Health Department at 605-698-7606 or 605-742-3808 to schedule an appointment. They may suggest counseling or medication (ask what is safe to take if you are breastfeeding): 
	• “I feel very sad and helpless” 
	• “I have trouble sleeping” 
	• “I want to sleep all the time” 
	• “I don’t feel like eating” 
	• “I feel confused and distracted” 
	• “I don’t think I can be a good mother” 
	• “I feel anxious and get angry easily” 
	• “I’m not interested in my baby” 
	• “I don’t want to get dressed or do daily tasks” 
	• “I’m constantly worried about my baby” 
	• “I don’t want to see friends and family” 
• Get help right away if you have thoughts of harming your baby or yourself. Call a child abuse hotline (1-800-633-5155), a mental health crisis hotline (1-800-444-3989), or 911 
• For more information, visit PPD Hope www.ppdhope.org and Postpartum Support International www.postpartum.net (1-800-944-4PPD). Your doctors and nurses at IHS, the WIC, and Coteau are all there to help and can point you to the right resource.


PPD can be treated! Take steps to help keep yourself and your new baby healthy. Asking for help can be hard, but the sooner you get help, the sooner you can start feeling better. PPD is not your fault. Remember, PPD is an illness. Your feelings don’t mean you are a ‘bad’ person or did something wrong.


Take care of yourself. There’s a lot you can do on your own to feel better. 
• Share your feelings with a friend or family member 
• Get proper rest and nutrition: try to sleep when your baby sleeps. Eat healthy meals and snacks. Stay healthy so you can give your baby the best! 
• Enjoy fresh air and sunshine. Try to spend some time outside every day. Even a short walk can make a difference 
• Rely on family and friends. You don’t have to do it all. Ask for help with chores and housework

string.name: meds_title
string.b: Medications and Supplements Considered Safe During Pregnancy

resources.string:
While these medications are generally considered safe in pregnancy, it is important to discuss them with your pre-natal doctor before taking, and always follow the guidelines on the label. Only take them in the prescribed quantities. 

Antacids: 
• Maalox 
• Mylanta 
• Nexium 
• Pepcid 
• Prevacid 
• Prilosec OTC 
• Rolaids 
• Tums 
• Zantac


Antibiotics: 
• Amoxicillin

Breastfeeding your baby is both physically and psychologically good for your newborn child. However, there may be a number of reasons that breastfeeding is not the best option for you. It doesn’t make you a bad mother to use alternatives to breastfeeding. Talking with a doctor or family member can help you make this personal decision.


Pros 
• Breastmilk provides baby with antibodies to fight diseases and prevents allergies 
• Economical and efficient (no bottle to prepare, etc.) 
• Whole nutrition 
• Burns calories 
• Helps uterus contract to normal size after delivery 
• Can delay the return of periods


Cons 
• Time-consuming 
• Breastfeeding moms must maintain a healthy diet. You must be careful about the types of medications you can take and pay attention to the food you eat, because harmful components in food or medicine can be passed to the baby. 
• May be painful to some mothers 
• May be stressful and feel like an additional burden


“Latching on” is how your baby breastfeeds. The following step can help you to obtain a good latch. 
1. Position nipple with thumb on top and fingers underneath breast 
2. Make sure your baby is stomach-to-stomach with you and has his or her chin tilted back from the chest 
3. Touch your nipple to your baby’s upper lip until the mouth opens very wide 
4. Insert the entire nipple into your baby’s mouth and pull your baby close to your body (but don’t lean into your baby) 
5. Both lips should “pout out” and cover almost the entire areola (the areola is the portion of pigmented skin surrounding your nipple). 
	• If your baby’s lips are not “pouting”, you can use your finger to pull them into the proper position 
	• Your baby’s tongue should be down and the cheeks should be rounded 
6. Keep your baby’s body in alignment to help swallowing 
	• You should hear swallowing, not smacking noises when your baby is feeding 
7. If your baby is moving his or her jaw circularly when feeding, it’s a good sign. 
8. Your nipple shouldn’t be flattened or misshapen at end of feeding


Positioning yourself and the baby is also an important step in breastfeeding.

• Lean back in a comfortable, supportive chair 
• Use a pillow or place feet up on stool 
• Pick the position that is most comfortable for you (Reclining may be your best option if you are recovering from a C-section)


 What is your let-down reflex? This happens several seconds or a couple minutes into breastfeeding when milk flows more easily and quickly. The quick release of milk may cause your baby to cough. To prevent this, before beginning feeding, rub you breast until milk begins to drip so that let-down happens before your baby has latched on. It can also happen if feeding is overdue or if your baby is crying. In these cases, milk may drip from unused breast or you may feel a tingle. If you’re having trouble with let-down, it means that you may be stressed or rushed. It can help, in these cases, to hold something that smells like or reminds you of your baby


The amount of milk you produce can vary based on you and your situation. Talk with your doctor, a nurse at the WIC’s Breastfeeding Peer Counselor program, or other family members if you are worried at all.


You may have some soreness, dryness, or discomfort associated with breastfeeding. Limiting feeding time may not necessarily help and may even lead to further discomfort. Here are some ways that you can reduce this pain. 
• Proper latching: Start over if not properly latched (Release suction by putting your finger in corner of your baby’s mouth). 
• Apply crushed ice or cold compress before feeding 
• Position any sore part of nipple in corner of baby’s mouth 
• Change positions 
• Allow nipples to air dry between feedings 
• Avoid lotions or soaps that may have alcohol in them. 
• Avoid bra pads lined with plastic. 
• Nipple cream can ease soreness immediately (short-term) 
• Express milk until let-down (see above). Sometimes, your milk ducts may not fully empty, leading to swelling and discomfort


If you aren’t able to produce enough milk or your schedule doesn’t allow for breastfeeding, you may consider using a breast pump. If you decide to bottle feed your baby, it may cause “nipple confusion.” This occurs when your baby uses the same techniques from bottle feeding on breasts, causing difficulty in latching on. So, it can be more difficult to switch back to breastfeeding after bottle feeding. 
• Start pumping a couple weeks before going back to work 
• Electric vs. Manual pumps 
• Manual: cheaper but more physical exertion 
• Electric: more expensive, but can pump both breasts at once 
• May be better for moms with busy schedules 
• Noise of electric pump may be annoying to some women 
• Avoid used pumps unless it is sterilized 
• Make sure your pump fits your breast


You can also use formula feeding if you are not able to breastfeed or pump your breastmilk. The WIC provides assistance with formula, both financially for those who qualify and through education.


When breastfeeding or using a pump to bottle-feed, it’s important to pay attention to your diet. Many of the things you consume will be given to your baby through your breast milk. 
• Stay hydrated 
• Eat a well-balanced diet—whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and good fats 
• Eat fish, which contain omega-3, DHA, and EPA. Avoid fish, like tuna, that may have a high mercury content. 
• Eat lean meats, which have a relatively low content of harmful chemicals 
• Avoid fruits and vegetables with high levels of pesticides 
• Try not to diet while breastfeeding. During this time, your body will need about 500 more calories a day than normal 
• Do not drink alcohol, smoke, use marijuana, illicit drugs, or misuse prescription drugs, because these substances can be passed onto your baby through milk. If you are planning on drinking alcohol, wait 2-3 hours to feed or pre-pump 
• Avoid caffeine 
• Take vitamins (DHA, vitamin D, and calcium)


You may be concerned about different medications you may be taking and how it will affect your breastmilk. LactMed (https://toxnet.nlm.nih.gov/newtoxnet/lactmed.htm) is a good resource where you can search for your medication and find its effect on breastmilk and possible alternatives.

Getting ready for your hospital visit can make it less stressful when the time actually comes to deliver your baby, and allow you to focus more on your experience. Here are some things to know prior to delivery: 
• Know when to go to the hospital 
• Be pre-registered at the hospital where you plan to give birth 
• Have your preferences for labor and delivery 
• Know day and night phone numbers for your health care provider's office and the labor and delivery unit 
• Have transportation to the hospital 
• Know where to go when you get to the hospital (including the after-hours entrance) 
• Have arrangements made if you plan to donate your cord blood


What to pack for the hospital: 
• Medical coverage information 
• Gift for sibling(s) from the baby 
• Support or nursing bra and breast pads 
• Socks and slippers 
• Lip balm 
• Snacks for labor partner 
• Music CDs that you would like to listen to during labor 
• Loose fitting clothes to wear home 
• Toothbrush, toothpaste, and hairbrush or comb 
• Telephone numbers of family and friends 
• Infant sleeper with legs (sacs or kimonos won't fit in the car seat), or T-shirt and a diaper for baby to wear home 
• Baby blanket 
• Infant car seat 
• Camera


Regular contractions usually mean you are beginning labor. False labor is commonly characterized by 
• Contractions that stop if you move around or on their own 
• Irregular contractions 
• Contractions that don’t get stronger or closer together over time 

Contact your doctor if 
• Your contractions are very strong or painful 
• You think you may be experiencing pre-term labor 
• Your contractions are 5-10 minutes apart 
• Your water breaks, especially if fluid is stained dark greenish brown 
• You experience vaginal bleeding 
• You cannot walk or talk during contractions 

If you need help getting to the hospital, arrange rides with a family member, partner, or friend ahead of time. Inquire at the Maternal Child Health program (MCH) to see if they still offer transportation. You’ll need to go to Coteau de Prairies Healthcare System for delivery, since IHS only has prenatal clinics. Some families at Sisseton choose to deliver in Sioux Falls in order to guarantee access to emergency care. No matter where you choose to deliver, arrange ahead of time and come up with a plan with your partner, family members, or a trusted nurse.

Being familiar with the signs of pregnancy complications can allow you to catch diseases in the early stages, which can help improve your outcome. Here is an overview of common and/or severe pregnancy complications, their symptoms, and screening and treatment procedures available.


Typical experiences in pregnancy include: 
• Nausea 
• Vomiting 
• Dizziness 

If you are experiencing the following, however, you should take note and speak to a doctor. 
• Bleeding/leaking vaginal fluid 
• Blurred vision or seeing flashes/spots of light 
• Unusual or severe abdominal pain or backaches 
• Strong cramps 
• Frequent, severe, or continuous headaches 
• Contractions 
• Decrease in the baby’s movements 
• Fainting 
• Excessive vomiting or diarrhea 
• Fever about 100 F/38 C 
• Pain or burning during urination 
• Inability to urinate 
• Chills 
• Severe or sudden swelling of the hands, face, or feet 
• Inability to tolerate food or liquid 
• Muscular convulsions


Gestational Diabetes 
There are three types of diabetes: 
• Gestational 
• Type 1 
• Type 2 
Gestational diabetes is characterized by elevated blood sugar that begins or is first recognized in pregnancy. This condition occurs in approximately 2-5 percent of pregnancies 
This condition can raise the risk for the following conditions, if you have it: 
• Birth defects 
• High blood pressure 
• Pre-eclampsia 
• Loss of pregnancy 
• Needing a C-section 
• Infections 
• Development of type 2 diabetes post-partum 
In your baby, gestational diabetes can cause: 
• Rapidly fluctuating blood sugar levels 
• Jaundice 
• Breathing problems 
• Higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes 
The risk factors for this condition are: 
• Overweight (BMI of 25+) (pop-up of image https://cdn.vertex42.com/ExcelTemplates/Images/bmi-chart.gif). 
• 25+ years old 
• Native American 
• History of high blood sugar during pregnancy 
• Lack of exercise/general inactivity 
• Previous delivery of a large infant (over 8 lbs., 13 oz.) 
• History of stillbirth, previous miscarriage, and/or birth defects 
• Current pregnancy of unexplained polyhydramnios (an excess of amniotic fluid in the bag of waters), persistent glycosuria (abnormal amount of sugar in urine) 
• Familial history (parent or sibling) of diabetes 
Screening 
• If you have a familial history of diabetes or gestational diabetes, you should ask your doctor to be screened. Screening involves drinking a glucose solution and the doctor measuring your blood glucose levels after an hour. 
To maintain lower weight during pregnancy: 
• Monitor blood glucose levels and blood pressure frequently 
• Take prenatal vitamins 
• Eating a proper, balanced diet 
• Regularly visit physician/doctor


Premature Birth 
Definition: birth prior to 37 weeks of pregnancy 
• Birth prior to 32 weeks of pregnancy can result in the most severe complications 
Risk factors 
• In vitro fertilization 
• Low age of pregnancy 
• High age of pregnancy 
• Infection 
• Prior pre-term birth 
• Carrying multiple babies (twins, triplets, etc) 
• High blood pressure during pregnancy 
• Tobacco use 
• Alcohol use 
• Use of illicit drugs or alcohol 
• High stress 
• Substance abuse 
• Fetal anomalies 
Harmful effects of pre-term birth for infant 
• Leading cause of infant death among children born 32 weeks into pregnancy or earlier 
• Leading cause of neurological disorders 
• Breathing problems 
• Feeding difficulties 
• Cerebral palsy (CP) (A disease in which the part of the brain controlling voluntary movement is damaged. This disease may not be detected until the child is a few months or years old. CP is generally characterized by uncoordinated or exaggerated movement, spasms, and can also lead to seizures, hearing or vision loss, pain and bladder or bowel control issues). 
• Developmental delay 
• Vision problems 
• Hearing impairment 
Warning signs 
• Contractions every 10 minutes or less 
• Change in vaginal discharge (increase in fluid, discharge, or blood) 
• Pelvic pressure (as if the baby is pushing down) 
• Dull lower backache 
• Cramps like menstrual period 
• Abdominal cramps without diarrhea 
Ways to help prevent pre-term births: 
• Stop smoking 
• Avoid alcohol, illegal drugs, and misuse of prescription drugs 
• Keep up with prenatal care appointments and regimens and begin prenatal care as early as possible 
• Progesterone medications (17-alpha hydroxyprogesterone caproate, or 17P) may reduce the risk of premature birth in women who have already had pre-term babies 
• C-section birth should not be scheduled prior to 39 weeks of pregnancy 
• Seek medical help immediately if you believe that you are experiencing symptoms of pre-term labor 
Emotional support for parents of pre-term babies : 
• http://www.marchofdimes.org/baby/becoming-a-parent-in-the-nicu.aspx 
There is no Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for pre-term babies at IHS or Coteau in Sisseton, and you will have to arrange for care in Sioux Falls or Minneapolis.


Pre-eclampsia 
Definition 
• Hypertension (high blood pressure) present before pregnancy (chronic) or develops during (gestational, pregnancy-induced) 
• Identified by the presence of excess protein in the urine, which is caused by kidney problems 
• Development of preeclampsia can cause serious and potentially life-threatening complications during labor 
Risk factors 
• Personal/familial history of preeclampsia 
• Pregnant with first child 
• Younger than 20 or older than 40 
• Previously obese 
• Carrying multiple fetuses 
• Chronic high blood pressure 
• Diabetes 
• Kidney disease 
• Rheumatoid arthritis 
• Lupus 
Signs and symptoms 
• More obvious symptoms include 
• Sudden, rapid weight gain 
• Swelling of the face or hands 
• Severe or constant headaches 
• Vision problems, including blurred vision 
• Pain in the upper part of the abdomen, especially on the right side 
• Decreased urine output 
Screening and diagnosis 
• Regular visits are the best way to track blood pressure and protein concentration in urine 
Potential complications 
• Decrease the amount of air/nutrients that the baby receives 
• Causes low birth weight, premature birth, or even stillbirth 
• Placental abruption 
• Placenta separates from the uterine wall before delivery 
• Rare, but potentially life-threatening for mother and baby 
• Heart, kidney, liver, brain, and eye damage 
• Problems with blood clotting 
• Eclampsia 
• Can induce seizures 
Treatment 
• Delivery is the only “cure” 
• If pre-eclampsia develops early, the mother may need to remain in the hospital for sustained monitoring 
• Regular prenatal care will help prevent severe complications 
Ask your doctor if you are at risk for pre-eclampsia. Complications resulting from this may mean emergency medical transportation to Sioux Falls.

It’s important for both men and women to be sexually responsible. Couples who don’t use any form of contraception have an 80 percent chance of becoming pregnant each year. If you’re not ready for sex or if you don’t feel like it’s right for your relationship, you always have the right to say “no” to sex. It’s your choice, and it shouldn’t be based on pressure from peers or your partner. You also decide (1) when you want to have kids, (2) how many kids you want, and (3) the spacing between your kids. Remember that if you have unprotected sex, you can get pregnant even if you are on your period or just gave birth. If you decide to have sex, but don’t want kids or want to have kids at a later time, there are many ways to prevent getting pregnancy. Before choosing a birth control method, talk to your doctor about advantages, disadvantages, and possible health risks of each one or consult a reliable online resource. 
To understand birth control, it’s important to first understand how your body prepares for pregnancy. 
The menstrual cycle is usually 21-35 days, and it begins with the shedding of your uterine lining. After this stage, which is normally called your “period,” a hormone in your body, follicle-stimulating hormone, helps to develop an egg in your ovary. This egg is released when another hormone, luteinizing hormone, spikes in your body. The released egg waits in your fallopian tube to meet a sperm cell (the cell from a male that fertilizes a female egg to create a baby). If the sperm cell, from the male, combines with the egg, from the female, the egg is fertilized in the first step to creating a baby. If the egg is not fertilized, it’s shed along with some of your uterine lining during your period. The following birth control methods can help to prevent your eggs from being fertilized if you don’t want to become pregnant. These methods focus on prevention of pregnancy, which means these methods are focused on being safe during vaginal sex rather than oral sex. You can find more information on the best ways to prevent STI’s during oral sex by talking to your OB/Gyn or primary care doctor. 

Abstinence (avoiding vaginal sex): 
Pros: 100 percent effective, no cost 
Cons: difficult to practice continuously 

The Pill: Several types are available, all containing certain hormones that either keep your egg from being released or prevent your egg from attaching to your uterine wall. Available as either (1) estrogen and progestin or (2) progestin only. If you decide to take the pill, you should take it every day. It might help to have a certain period/hour/time of day to take the pill. 
Pros: 
• Very effective (~99 percent) 
• Requires no preparation before sex 
• Benefits include lighter/shorter periods, improved acne, protection against some cancers and Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) 
Cons: 
• May be less effective if you are overweight, take certain antibiotics/antifungals, or have had GI issues like diarrhea or vomiting 
• Side effects include bleeding, breast tenderness, nausea/vomiting, weight gain, reduced libido (sex drive) 
• May cause mood changes if you have a history of anxiety or depression 
• If you smoke, the Pill should be used with caution 

Diaphragm and cervical cap and prevent sperm from fertilizing the egg): Before inserting the cap over the cervix, a cream or jelly is used inside the cup to kill sperm, and it can be inserted up to six hours before sex. The diaphragm has a 6 percent chance of failure. In other words, if you use the diaphragm to avoid pregnancy, there’s a 6 percent chance that you could become pregnant. 
Pros: 
• Can be used be almost all women 
• May protect against some sexually transmitted infections (STIs) 
Cons: 
• May cause side effects, such as discomfort 
• Must be inserted before sex 

Female condom (lines the vagina).The female condom has a 5 percent chance of failure. 
Pros: 
• Reduces STI’s 
• Easy to get 
Cons: 
• Must be inserted immediately before sex 

Male condom (fits over the penis to stop the sperm from entering the vagina): The failure rate for a condom can vary between 2 and 18 percent based on how well you and your partner use this method. Some condoms are coated with spermicide, which kills male sperm. This can help to prevent pregnancy. 
Pros: 
• Protects against STIs 
• Easy to get 
Cons: 
• Must be put on immediately before sex 

Chemical barriers (A sperm-killing foam, cream, or tablet is inserted into the vagina before sex). The failure rate ranges from 18 to 28 percent, but this method is more effective when used with a male or female condom. 
Pro: 
• Easy to get 
• Reduces STI’s 
Cons: 
• Must use immediately before sex 
• May cause side-effects 
• Not effective 

Implant (a small implantable rods inserted under the skin in the upper arm): The implant, called Nexplanon, slowly releases a hormone (progestin) that prevent your egg from being released. Implants have a failure rate of less than 1 percent each year. 
Pros: 
• Reversible 
• Can be effective for 3 - 5 years 
• Effective (>99 percent) 
• “Invisible” (no preparation required before sex) 
Cons: 
• Can be expensive 
• May cause irregular periods and other side effects 
• Can only get an implant by making an appointment and seeing a doctor 

Contraceptive injection (injection of a hormone (progestin)). The injection, commonly known as Depo-Provera, prevents your egg from being released. It has a failure rate of less than 1 percent. You can go to a provider to get the shot or buy SubQ Depo and give yourself the shot. 
Pros: 
• Effective (>99 peercent) 
• Lasts for 3 months 
Cons: 
• Side effects 
• The method itself may be painful 
• Must remember every three months to get another shot 

Fertility awareness methods (modifying your sexual activity based on observing your physical changes): There are different ways that you can tell when you’re fertile, including the texture of your cervical mucus and your basal body temperature. You can ask your doctor about these methods or use a reliable online source. Since it can be difficult to use this method, it has a failure rate of up to 25 percent. 
Pros: 
• No special equipment or prescriptions required 
• Effective if used correctly 
• No preparation before sex 
Cons: 
• Must avoid sex for at least 8 days every month 
• Can be difficult to use this method perfectly 
• Can be time consuming - must observe bodily changes everyday 
• Patch (hormones (estrogen and progestin) delivered through a patch on the skin). The hormones prevent an egg from being released from your ovaries. To use this method, you place a patch on your skin each week for three weeks, then have no patch the following week. It has similar side effects and benefits as the pill. 
Pros: 
• Don’t need to remember to take every day 
• Predictable periods 
Cons: 
• Less effective if you are overweight or on certain medications 
• Side effects, which can be made worse if you’re over 35 and smoke 

Vaginal Ring (hormones (estrogen and progestin) delivered through a flexible plastic ring, inserted in the vagina). To use the ring, also called the NuvaRing, you insert and leave it in for three weeks, then take it out for the fourth week. The failure rate is about 1 percent. 
Pros: 
• May reduce anemia (which happens if you have low iron in your blood) and PMS 
• Don’t need to remember to take every day 
• Has a lower dose of hormones, which may mean less side effects 
Cons: 
• Side effects, including bleeding between your periods 

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) (a device that is inserted into uterus by a qualified healthcare provider): IUDs can either be hormonal or non-hormonal. Hormonal IUD’s release a small amount of progestin to thicken your cervical mucus. You will still release an egg, but it will be difficult for sperm to reach this egg. Non-hormonal IUD’s, made of plastic and copper, kill sperm within the uterus so that it can’t fertilize your egg. The failure rate is less than 1 percent. 
Pros: 
• Effective for 3-6 years (hormonal) and up to 12 years (non-hormonal) 
Cons: 
• Side effects include cramps, heavy periods, bleeding between periods, and a greater risk of STI’s 
• Can only get an IUD by making an appointment and seeing a doctor 

Permanent sterilization or your partner’s reproductive organs): You can get a tubal ligation, which requires surgery, or implant, which are insertions placed in your fallopian tubes to block them. Your partner can get a vasectomy to block sperm from leaving the penis. These methods are permanent and have a 1 percent rate of failure. 
Pros: 
• Effective indefinitely 
Cons: 
• Cannot regain fertility if you change your mind 
• May require surgery 

If you have unprotected sex or you think your contraceptive method may have failed, you can take the morning-after pill or have a doctor insert an IUD within 5 days to prevent pregnancy.

First prenatal check up 
Northern Plains and IHS both offer pre-natal visits. When you schedule an appointment, be sure to ask about what other information you will need. 

Your provider will gather general health information and information that may have an effect on your pregnancy: 
• Date of your last menstrual period (This helps your provider to determine your due date.) 
• Health problems, like diabetes, high blood pressure or sexually transmitted infections STIs 
• Past pregnancies (for example, if you had a preterm birth or miscarriage before) 
• Past hospital stays 
• Medicines you’re taking or if you’re allergic to any medicines 
• Lifestyle, such as if you drink alcohol, smoke or use street drugs like marijuana or ecstasy 
• Exercise or other activities you do 
• Stress you feel 
• Safety of your environment 
• Your family health history (Talk to your family members related to you by blood to learn about any diseases or illnesses that run in your family.) 
• Your partner’s family health history 
Some routine tests and exams will be done 
• Your weight will be determined 
• Your blood pressure will be taken 
• You will have a physical exam and a pelvic (internal) exam 
• Your urine will be checked for infection 
• You will have various blood tests to check for anemia and to see if you have certain infections. You will be offered a blood test for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, but you have a right to say “no” 
• You may have a Pap smear to check for cervical cancer and other tests for vaginal infections 
• You will also receive a prescription for a prenatal vitamin with 600 micrograms of folic acid 

In later prenatal check-ups, a doctor or nurse will 
• Check your weight 
• Take your blood pressure 
• Measure your belly to see how your baby is growing (second and third trimesters) 
• Check your hands, feet and face for swelling 
• Listen for the baby's heartbeat (after the 12th week of pregnancy) 
• Feel your belly to find your baby's position (later in pregnancy) 
• You may have other blood tests, or ultrasound examinations as needed 
• Talks to you about your questions or concerns


Reasons for having an ultrasound 
• To confirm you’re pregnant and make sure that the pregnancy is in the right place. 
• To check your baby’s age and growth. This helps your provider figure out your due date. 
• To check your baby’s heartbeat, muscle tone, movement and overall development 
• To check to see if you’re pregnant with twins, triplets or more (also called multiples) 
• To screen for birth defects, like spina bifida or heart defects. Screening means seeing if your baby is more likely than others to have a health condition; it doesn’t mean finding out for sure if your baby has the condition. After an ultrasound, your provider may want to do more tests, called diagnostic tests, to see for sure if your baby has a birth defect. Birth defects are health conditions that a baby has at birth. 
• To help with other optional prenatal tests like amniocentesis 
• To examine your ovaries (Ovaries are where eggs are stored in your body) and uterus (womb). 
• To check for pregnancy complications such as a miscarriage 
Types of ultrasound include… 
Transabdominal ultrasound: 
• The most common type of an ultrasound 
• You lie on your back and your provider covers your stomach in a thin layer of gel. Then, your provider will move a wand across your abdomen, called a transducer. The transducer sends sound waves through you skin and an image of the baby can then be seen on a TV monitor. 
Transvaginal ultrasound: 
• This ultrasound is done through the vagina 
• A thin transducer will be inserted into your vagina 
• You may feel pressure from the transducer, but it should not be painful 
• This type of ultrasound is usually done early in pregnancy or if the baby is difficult to see. 
A couple of other specialized ultrasounds may be used under special circumstances 
Ultrasound is safe for you and your baby. It is safer than X-ray since sound waves are used instead of radiation to detect your baby.


First trimester prenatal tests 
These tests can be preformed at the IHS prenatal clinic, or with other prenatal healthcare providers, but be sure to request them if they’re not immediately offered. 

Chorionic villus sampling (also called CVS) 
A test that uses a small piece of tissue from the placenta (The placenta is the structure that provides oxygen and nutrients to your growing baby and removes waste products from your baby's blood. The placenta attaches to the wall of your uterus, and your baby's umbilical cord arises from it.) to see if a baby has a genetic condition, like Down syndrome. 
CVS is usually performed between 11 and 13 weeks of pregnancy. 
• Your provider may offer you to have CVS if: 
• You are 35 or older 
• You have a genetic condition that “runs in your family.” 
• Your first-trimester screening shows that your baby is at increased risk for birth defects 
Cystic fibrosis (CF is a disease that affects breathing and digestion. It is a lifelong disease that cannot be cured, but can be treated.) (also called CF) carrier screening. 
A blood test to see if you are carrier of a gene for CF 
Carriers of the gene are not affected with CF, but can pass that gene to a baby. If the father is also a carrier, there is a possibility that you both will pass on the gene for CF and the baby will have the disease. 
Cystic fibrosis is more common in Caucasians but is found in all ethnic groups 
You and your partner can have this test any time during pregnancy 
First-trimester screening 
• Done between 11 to 14 weeks of pregnancy 
• A test to see if your baby may be at risk for some birth defects, like Down syndrome. 
• It is a two-part test that includes a blood test and an ultrasound. 
Second trimester prenatal tests 
Maternal blood screening (also called Quad screen) 
• Done at 15 to 22 weeks of pregnancy 
• Tests your blood to see if your baby is at risk for three birth defects: Down syndrome, spina bifida and trisomy 18. 
• It is called a Quad screen because it measures four substances in the mother's blood: alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), estriol, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and inhibin A 
Amniocentesis (also called amnio) 
• Usually done at 15 to 20 weeks of pregnancy 
• Tests the amniotic fluid from around your baby to see if he/she has a genetic condition, like Down syndrome 
• Your provider may offer you an amniocentesis for the same reasons as you might have a CVS (see above) 
Glucose screening 
A test to see if you have gestational diabetes (see “Pregnancy Complications”) This is a kind of diabetes that some women get during pregnancy 
Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that generally resolves after the end of pregnancy. It’s caused by too much glucose in the blood and too little insulin, which helps to absorb your blood glucose. 
This condition can lead to: 
• Pre-eclampsia 
• Premature birth 
• Your baby may be heavier, increasing the risk of injury to your baby during labor/birth. 
• Your baby may be more likely to develop diabetes and be overweight later in life 
• You get this test at 24 to 28 weeks of pregnancy.


Third trimester prenatal tests: 
• Group B strep (also called GBS) 
• Done at 35 to 37 weeks of pregnancy. 
• Group B strep is an infection you can pass to your baby during birth. GBS is usually not serious for adults, but can be for newborns. Many adults carry GBS without every showing symptoms, but in newborns, it can cause meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia. 
• The test checks fluid from your cervix to see if you have GBS 
• If your test is positive, your doctor will administer a treatment (generally an intravenous dose of an antibiotic like penicillin) during birth to prevent your baby from becoming infected. It’s not necessary or helpful to take an antibiotic before beginning labor 
• GBS infection can lead to preterm labor, premature rupture of the amniotic sack (your water breaks early), and still-birth

Provides: community based program utilizing paraprofessional Community Health Workers to deliver a variety of services to women and childbearing age, their partners, and children from birth to 24 months. 

1. Case Management: Your case manager can help you design an individualized case plan to meet your needs. Some of the things your case manager can help you with include: assessment to determine your needs and identify potential barriers to a healthy pregnancy, help to meet those needs and reduce the barriers, support to complete paperwork and apply for services you are eligible for, advocacy to help you get the services you need, help to find resources in your community, job search counseling, help with budgeting, and encouragement to help you reach your goals. 
2. Health and Life Skills Education: The Community Health Workers are trained to provide you with the latest information on prenatal and post-partum care, family planning, child development, and infant and toddler care. They can also help you with basic life skills such as organization, cooking, meal planning, budgeting, and more. 
3. Screening and Referral: Are you struggling with depression, addiction, relationship problems? Do you want to complete your education? Want to stop smoking? The Community Health Workers can help you identify problems and provide you with referrals to professionals who can help you and your baby thrive! 
4. Home Visiting: Do you want services, but don/’t know how you will get there? The Community Health Workers provide home visiting services to bring first class Health and Life Skills education right into your home, using the Family Spirit curriculum. Culturally appropriate education modules make learning easy interesting, and fun. 
5. Enabling Services: Is it difficult to get to prenatal, postpartum, or well child appointments? They can provide transportation services to help you get to appointments. Does visiting the doctor make you nervous? We provide accompaniment services. Your community health worker may be able to attend appointments with you. (Accompaniment and transportation services may be limited by funding or staff availability).

Provides: services to help improve the health of residents of Roberts County, South Dakota 
WIC, Family Planning, Immunizations, Cribs for Kids, ASQ/ASQ:SE Screening, Breastfeeding Support, Baby Care (Case Management for Pregnant Women), Reach Out and Read


WIC: 
• Patient population: Pregnant women, Postpartum women (up to 6 months) and breastfeeding women up to 1 year, children aged 0-5 
• Immunizations: children age 0 up until 19 birthday, and all ages for flu vaccines 
• Family Planning: Adolescent and Adult men and women 
• Case Management: Pregnant women 
• Cribs for Kids: A care provider in need of a safe place for infant to sleep that participates in any assistance program including but not limited to Medicaid, Energy Assistance, SNAP, WIC, etc. 
Oral Health: Education on dental health/oral care, provide toothbrushes/toothpaste, quick screenings and referrals 
Mental Health: Discuss client/’s concerns about depression/anxiety, provide contact information to referral sources. 
Well Child: 
• Discuss healthy nutrition, dental care, exercise, life style choices 
• Complete ASQ (Ages and Stages Questionnaire) and ASQ:SE (Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional) screenings 
• Provide immunizations 
• Check hemoglobins 
• Take height and weight measurements and make referrals as appropriate to dental, health, mental health, schools etc. 
• Provide children with books through the reach out and read program and discuss the importance of reading to child. 
Prenatal Care: 
• Monthly visits for pregnant women that discusses healthy habits during pregnancy 
• Monitor blood pressure and weight 
• Assess substance use 
• Monitor for signs of preterm labor or warning signs 
• Discuss fetal kick counts 
• Referrals for car seats, prenatal care, oral care, etc. 
Labor and Giving Birth: 
• Discuss at case management and prenatal health review appointments, signs of labor, warning signs, etc. 
• Referrals made to hospital and clinic as appropriate, also to prenatal classes at Sanford Watertown, IHS and CDP. 
Family Planning: 
• Provide services on a sliding scale fee which includes annual exams, birth control pills, injections or devices. 
• Provide education on STI, pregnancy prevention, safe sex practices. Screening for STIs, and pregnancy tests done. Available for teens and adults. 
Home Visiting: 
• Complete risk assessment on pregnant women, and, depending on needs found, referrals made to Bright Start or Healthy Start Programs 
• Offer postpartum women and infants home visits following delivery, which include wellness checks, health assessment, and weight/length measurements 
• Advocacy: Referrals as needed 
Special Needs: 
• ASQ (Ages and Stages Questionnaire) and ASQ:SE (Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional) completed; when needs are identified referrals are made to Early Childhood Intervention, Birth to Three or local school district 
• Education Setting: Assess for needs/concerns by completing ASQ and ASQ:SEs. Referrals made to Head Start, preschools, and local school districts. 
• Referrals also made to GED programs when pregnant or postpartum women verbalize a desire to complete GED. 
Breastfeeding Support: 
• Hands-on assistance with latch or breastfeeding problems 
• Referrals to lactation consultants as needed 
• Weighted feedings 
• Breastpumps including manual, hospital grade double electric, and single user pumps. 
Child Development: 
• Education, and assessment by completing ASQ (Ages and Stages Questionnaire) and ASQ:SE (Ages and Stages Questionnaire: Social-Emotional) 
• Referrals to Early Childhood Intervention, Schools, and Birth to Three as needed 
• Parenting: Assess needs of parents at WIC appointments, such as stressors, need for support, child care resources, etc., and referrals made as needed. 
Hardship Assistance: 
• Provide vouchers through the WIC program for food 
• Provide pack n/’ plays for infants to sleep through the Cribs for Kids program 
• Assess needs of families at each appointment and referrals made to social services, the "kitchen", homeless shelter, women/’s shelters, etc.

To apply for Medicaid in the state of South Dakota, print and fill out this application (http://dss.sd.gov/formsandpubs/docs/MEDELGBLTY/FSSA.pdf). Mail, fax, or deliver your application to a Department of Social Services local office. You can also call 1-800-305-3064 to request that an application be sent to you. You don’t need an interview to apply for Medicaid, but you can request one. The start date of medical coverage depends on the date that the application is received. You may be covered up to three months before the month the application is received if you have unpaid medical bills and meet eligibility requirements. In this case, you should provide proof of your income from the three months prior to the month you submitted the application. If you’re having trouble navigating the application or have more questions, you can contact Marsha Renville, the SWO Benefits Coordinator, at 605-742-3628 or 605-698-7606 or by visiting her office at the IHS building. Here are specific medical programs, what they entail, and their eligibility. The SNAP, Medicaid, CHIP, TANF, and Child Protection Services are located at 10 E. Hickory St, Sisseton, SD 57262-1425 in the same building as the WIC. You can call them at 605-698-7673 or 1-888-747-0017. 

Medicaid 
Low-Income Families

Medicaid for Certain Newborns 
Coverage for your baby from birth until the end of the month of your baby’s first birthday. 
Eligibility: You must be eligible and receiving South Dakota Medicaid on the date of your baby’s birth 

Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) 
Provides quality health care (including regular check-ups, Well-Child Care exams, dental and vision care) for children and youth. 
Eligibility: Children must be under the age of 19 and current residents of South Dakota. Children who are uninsured or already have health insurance may be eligible for CHIP based on income and eligibility guidelines (below).

Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) 
Provides an EBT (electronic benefit transfer) card, which is loaded with benefits once a month. Household members may use it to purchase food at one of the 261,000 retailers authorized to participate in the program. SNAP cannot be used to purchase alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, vitamin supplements, non-food grocery items such as household supplies, or hot foods. 
Retailers in Sisseton that accept EBT (Check online for stores in nearby towns that accept EBT): 
• ALCO Discount Store 211 
• Family Dollar Store 7227 
• Hortons Processing 
• Huber Family Bakery 
• Jemms Fuel Max 
• Pamida 652 
• Teal’s Market 

Fill out application here (http://dss.sd.gov/formsandpubs/docs/GEN/301Application.pdf) 
Income eligibility (more detailed eligibility requirements can be found on the application)

Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) 
Designed to provide temporary assistance and encourage economic self-sufficiency for children and families. An adult may not receive for more than 60 months (5 years). These months of assistance don’t need to be consecutive or within the same state. Can qualify for monthly payments if you are in serious financial need. Talk to your local TANF office at 10 E. Hickory Street or at 605-698-7673.


Eligibility: 
• Children under the age of 18 (or under 19 if the child is in high school) 
• Need financial support because of: a death of a parent, a parent is absent from the home, or physical or mental incapacity or unemployment of a parent



Breast and Cervical Cancer Program 
Provides treatment for breast or cervical cancer, including pre-cancerous conditions and early stage cancer


Eligibility: 
• You must have screened for breast and cervical cancer under the Breast and Cervical Cancer Control Program, administered by the Department of Health. 
• You must be uninsured. 
• You must meet age requirements (under 65 years old). 
• Your yearly income can be up to $23,544.



MAWD (Medicaid for Workers with Disabilities) 
This program allows individuals with disabilities to return to work or remain working 

Eligibility: 
• You must be employed. 
• You must have a significant disability. 
• You must have resources less than $8000. 
• You must have less than $755 of monthly unearned income (money such as VA or SSDI, which is not earned from your job or business. 


Family Support Services 
Provides Medicaid for individuals with developmental disability such as Down\’s Syndrome, autism or cerebral palsy. Services include: standard Medicaid services, service coordination respite care, specialized medical and adaptive equipment and supplies, nutritional supplements, personal care, companion care, and environmental accessibility adaptations.


Eligibility (for your baby): 
• Your baby is found disabled by the Social security Administration or the Department of Social Services 
• Your baby lives in the family home with natural family, adopted family, stepfamily, or relatives



Disabled Children's Program

Provides Medicaid for children with disabilities who have medically fragile conditions, requiring skilled nursing care in a medical facility.


Eligibility: 
• Your baby/child must be under the age of 19 
• Your baby/child must be found disabled by the Social security Administration or the Department of Social Services 
• Your child/baby must require medical care in the home comparable to a level of care needed in a hospital, nursing facility or intermediate care facility. A child who is medically stable (doesn’t require care in a medical institution), even though disabled, is not considered in need of a level of care. 
• Health care services received in the home must have been ordered by a physician and could only be performed by a physician or nurse if the child were in a medical facility. 
• Cost of the child’s monthly health care services at home must be the same or less than the cost of treating the child within a medical facility. 
• The child’s monthly income must be less than 300 percent of the SSI Standard Benefit Amount ($2,205) and resources must be less than $2,000. (Resources include items such as checking and savings accounts and certificates of deposit.) Income and resources of the parents are not considered to determine eligibility.
